metadata.title: Global Spyware Scandal: Exposing Pegasus Part One (full documentary) | FRONTLINE
metadata.description:
Part one of a two-part docuseries: FRONTLINE and Forbidden Films investigate Pegasus, a powerful spyware sold to governments around the world by the Israeli company NSO Group.

This journalism is made possible by viewers like you. Support your local PBS station here: http://www.pbs.org/donate​.

In 2020, the journalism nonprofit Forbidden Stories and Amnesty International gained access to a leaked list of more than 50,000 phone numbers. They suspected it contained numbers selected for potential surveillance with Pegasus. The Pegasus Project reporting consortium — which was led by Forbidden Stories and included 16 other media organizations, FRONTLINE among them — found that the spyware had been used on journalists, human rights activists, the wife and fiancée of the murdered Saudi columnist Jamal Khashoggi, and others.

Over two nights, this docuseries reveals the inside story of an investigation that prompted probes by governments and institutions around the world and sparked calls for an international treaty to govern the largely unregulated spyware industry.

NSO, which has disputed some of the Pegasus Project’s reporting, says that its technology was not associated in any way with Khashoggi’s murder and that it sells Pegasus to vetted governments for “the sole purpose of preventing and investigating terror and serious crime.”

Surveillance technologies like Pegasus are “a military weapon used against civilians, and the civilians, they don’t have any mechanism to help them in seeking justice,” says Laurent Richard, founder of Forbidden Stories and Forbidden Films and one of the producers of the films.

Part two of “Global Spyware Scandal: Exposing Pegasus” premieres Tues., Jan. 10, 2023.

Learn more: https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/frontline/documentary/global-spyware-scandal-exposing-pegasus/

#Documentary #Spyware #Surveillance

Find FRONTLINE on the PBS App, where more than 300 of our documentaries are available to watch any time: https://to.pbs.org/FLVideoApp 
Subscribe on YouTube: http://bit.ly/1BycsJW 
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/frontlinepbs 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/frontlinepbs 
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/frontline 

“Global Spyware Scandal: Exposing Pegasus” is a FRONTLINE production with Forbidden Films. It is a film by Anne Poiret and Arthur Bouvart. The director is Anne Poiret. The producers are Laurent Richard and Sandrine Rigaud. The senior producers are Eamonn Matthews and Dan Edge. The editor-in-chief and executive producer of FRONTLINE is Raney Aronson-Rath. 

FRONTLINE is produced at GBH in Boston and is broadcast nationwide on PBS. Funding for FRONTLINE is provided through the support of PBS viewers and by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Additional support for FRONTLINE is provided by the Abrams Foundation, the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, Park Foundation, the Heising-Simons Foundation, and the FRONTLINE Journalism Fund, with major support from Jon and Jo Ann Hagler on behalf of the Jon L. Hagler Foundation, and additional support from Laura DeBonis.

CHAPTERS: 
Prologue - 00:00
Spyware That Turns Phones Into Surveillance Devices - 00:49
What Pegasus Spyware Does - 03:15
The Pegasus Project Begins - 09:57
Jamal Khashoggi’s Wife and Fiancée’s Phones Targeted With Pegasus - 13:38
Prominent Mexican Journalist On Being a Pegasus Spyware Target - 25:26
An Investigative Journalist Finds Out Her Phone Was Infected by Pegasus Spyware - 35:16
Pegasus Spyware: “A Military Weapon Used Against Civilians” - 50:26
Credits - 51:54

analysis.summary:
The transcript details a comprehensive global investigation into Pegasus, a powerful and controversial spyware developed by the Israeli company NSO Group. Originally marketed for combating terrorism and serious crime, Pegasus has been widely misused to monitor journalists, human rights activists, and dissidents across the globe. The investigation, a two-part series titled 'Global Spyware Scandal, Exposing Pegasus' by Frontline and Forbidden Films, revealed the alarming scale and impact of this surveillance, likening the technology's intrusive capabilities to something 'beyond science fiction' and even unimaginable by George Orwell.

The investigation was sparked by a leaked database containing approximately 50,000 phone numbers from 2016 to 2020. This massive undertaking involved an unprecedented collaboration of 17 news outlets and over 80 journalists, including prominent organizations like The Washington Post, The Guardian, and Le Monde. A critical challenge was identifying the individuals behind these numbers and forensically proving Pegasus infections, a task made possible by the crucial expertise of Claudio Ganyeri and the Amnesty International Security Lab. Pegasus, designed for iPhones and Androids, can compromise virtually all data on a device, including encrypted messages, and remotely activate microphones and cameras, effectively turning a personal phone into a pervasive surveillance tool.

Despite NSO Group's claims of selling Pegasus exclusively to governments for legitimate purposes and rigorous misuse prevention, the investigation uncovered widespread abuse, with targets identified in multiple countries such as India, Mexico, Hungary, Azerbaijan, and Kazakhstan. The scandal underscores the significant gap between the rapid advancement of surveillance technology and the lagging pace of government regulation and public understanding. The potential use of Pegasus against figures like Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed in 2018, highlights the severe real-world implications of this technology for privacy, human rights, and democratic processes.

key_points.text: Pegasus has been extensively used to monitor and track journalists, human rights activists, and dissidents globally.
The investigation is a two-part series titled 'Global Spyware Scandal, Exposing Pegasus' by Frontline, in collaboration with Forbidden Films.
NSO Group was established with the ambition to make the world a safer place.
Pegasus spyware is described as a 'military weapon used against civilians', highlighting its dangerous nature.
There is a significant lack of control over how countries use Pegasus, leading to its reported misuse.
The pervasive nature of phone surveillance is compared to a scenario even George Orwell couldn't imagine, highlighting its 'beyond science fiction' reality.
The technology of Pegasus is far ahead of government regulation and public understanding.
There was prior suspicion that NSO Group's powerful surveillance instrument would be abused by authoritarian regimes, but no systemic proof existed until this investigation.
The investigation was a joint effort by 17 news outlets, including The Washington Post, The Guardian, and Le Monde.
Activists, lawyers, and journalists are reportedly among those targeted by Pegasus spyware.
The investigation utilized a leaked database of approximately 50,000 phone numbers from 2016 to 2020.
The leaked list primarily contained phone numbers, country codes, and timestamps, but no names, requiring extensive identification work.
The source of the leaked phone number list remains undisclosed to protect confidentiality.
NSO Group officially states that Pegasus spyware does not work on +1 US phone numbers.
Most phone numbers on the leaked list are concentrated in 10 countries, whose governments are known clients of NSO Group.
Pegasus is designed to infect both iPhones and Android devices.
Once infected, Pegasus can extract and access all data from a device, including phonebooks, geolocation, messages, photos, and even encrypted messages from apps like Signal and WhatsApp.
Pegasus can remotely access and control the microphone and camera of an infected phone.
An infected phone effectively turns into a constant surveillance device, trapping the user.
The investigation involved reaching out to numerous media partners globally, including The Washington Post and The Guardian.
A major challenge for the investigation was identifying the individuals associated with the phone numbers and locating potential victims.
Specialized tech expertise was crucial for identifying numbers and conducting forensic analysis to confirm infections.
The sheer quantity of phone numbers (tens of thousands) on the leaked list was shocking to the investigative team.
The investigation uncovered significant concerns regarding the use of Pegasus in countries like India, Mexico, Hungary, Azerbaijan, and Kazakhstan.
Forbidden Stories possessing data that could identify both NSO customers and potential targets was considered a 'game changer' for understanding the cyber surveillance industry.
The Guardian had been reporting on NSO Group for a long time prior to this joint investigation.
Israel has emerged as a world leader in the cyber surveillance industry.
NSO Group is considered 'the jewel in the crown' of Israel's startup space.
NSO Group was recently valued at $1 billion.
NSO Group claims to sell its software exclusively to governments worldwide for legitimate purposes, such as fighting terrorism, solving serious crimes, and facilitating national security inquiries.
NSO Group claims to have 40 countries as clients for its technology.
NSO Group asserts that it has only found three cases of misuse in the last 10 years, and for these, it took 'very serious action,' including shutting down systems.
NSO Group claims to have mechanisms in place to ensure their customers do not misuse the systems.
The investigative team convened in Paris, during the COVID crisis, to plan the comprehensive investigation.
Journalists from typically rival news organizations collaborated unprecedentedly as partners for this complex story.
More than 80 journalists actively worked on the project.
A publication date of July 2021 was set, allowing approximately one year for the investigation.
Protecting the source of the leaked data was a critical priority for the investigative team.
The crucial primary task for all partners was to identify the names behind the leaked phone numbers.
Proving Pegasus infection on phones required sophisticated forensic analysis.
Claudio Ganyeri, head of Amnesty International Security Lab, developed the methodology and platform for analyzing phones for Pegasus traces.
Claudio Ganyeri's expertise was indispensable for detecting Pegasus traces in infected phones.
A crucial piece of information discovered was the rumor that Pegasus Spyware might have been used against Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed in 2018.

timeline_events.event_description: NSO Group was founded by three individuals.
A list of approximately 50,000 phone numbers, suspected to be targets of Pegasus spyware, was created or collected over this period.
involved_entities: Unnamed entities suspected of using Pegasus

timeline_events.event_description: The collection of the suspected Pegasus target list concludes around this time, encompassing numbers from 2016-2020.
involved_entities: Unnamed entities suspected of using Pegasus

timeline_events.event_description: Forbidden Stories, in collaboration with other partners, held a significant meeting in Paris during the COVID crisis to plan the global investigation into Pegasus spyware.
The publication date for the collaborative 'Global Spyware Scandal, Exposing Pegasus' investigation was set.
The 'Global Spyware Scandal, Exposing Pegasus' investigation, a two-part series, was published, revealing findings from the collaborative effort.

temporal_patterns.description: The consistent use of Pegasus spyware to monitor and track journalists, human rights activists, and dissidents across the globe, indicating a widespread and ongoing surveillance practice.
temporal_patterns.significance: Highlights the persistent nature and global reach of surveillance by states using Pegasus.

temporal_patterns.description: NSO Group's progression from its stated ambition to 'make the world a safer place' to developing powerful spyware now described as a 'military weapon used against civilians'.
temporal_patterns.significance: Illustrates a shift in the perceived or actual use-case and impact of the technology over time.

temporal_patterns.description: The observation that technology (specifically Pegasus spyware) is advancing much faster than government regulation and public understanding, leading to a persistent gap.
temporal_patterns.significance: Explains the challenges in controlling and comprehending sophisticated cyber surveillance capabilities.

temporal_patterns.description: The collaborative shift in journalistic practice from traditional competition to widespread partnership, involving over 80 journalists from various news organizations, to investigate complex stories like the Pegasus scandal.
temporal_patterns.significance: Demonstrates an evolution in how major investigations are conducted, moving towards greater inter-organizational cooperation.
temporal_patterns.timespan: Leading up to and during the 2020-2021 investigation

temporal_patterns.description: NSO Group's repeated claims that it sells software only to governments for 'legitimate purposes' like fighting terrorism, and its assertion of due diligence mechanisms to prevent misuse.
temporal_patterns.significance: Represents the company's consistent public stance and operational protocols regarding its product's intended use.

temporal_patterns.description: The systematic process of identifying individuals from raw phone numbers on a leaked list, involving extensive journalistic and technical collaboration.
temporal_patterns.significance: Highlights the methodical and complex nature of uncovering surveillance targets from technical data.
